had three rules step one grab the file step two upload an empty file with the

and see if anyone else uploaded a similar empty file if not delete your file and process what you grabbed if

at this this point and still today the entirety of store graph is two people me and my co-founder
Nadia think about the core components of a typical app the web server horizontally scalable elastic search
horizontally scalable but your primary database you just buy the biggest server you can find and hope it'll work because
nobody especially smaller companies wants to deal with manually sharting their database that this is what sharting your
database looks like sh is spitting up your data from one huge monolith into multiple smaller
pieces then moving those pieces to other servers then when a query comes through your app needs to know which servers
have the requested data and only those servers are touched doing this manually is very complicated keeping track of
which data is on which server sending queries to the right place handling outages when one of the servers is down
this is not fun a big advantage to yugabyte is that it's a fork of postgress it handles all the distribut
database stuff while maintaining query compatibility the query layer is forked and the back end is swapped out for
something that can natively handle horizontal scaling this means that my postgress libraries still work and most
of my postgress queries are just as fast we tested this for months and we
went live with a 10 server cluster on yugabyte with 960 cores two and half terabyt of ram 40 terab of hard drive
space for $2,000 a month about a third of the cost of a single Heroku database
that we used to have while all my queries worked some
particularly those with joins needed some modification as an example one particularly complicated query went from
100 milliseconds on postgress to 400 seconds on yugabyte after modification
we got it down to 50 milliseconds on yugabyte and we found that it always has to do with some combination of these
three factors to fix the query one CTE rewriting the query as a CTE
allows yugabyte to more efficiently split up the query into parts for separate servers to handle here's an
example this is a typical query that stereograph used to use and this is the CTE version looks
very similar but the one on the left takes 22 seconds compared to 20 milliseconds on
yugabyte this is as simple as copying the original query pasting it in chat GB
and asking it to rewrite it as a CTE I then test the new query on staging to see if it's faster and has the same
output when I say we live in awesome times this is what I'm talking about I have no idea what it would have taken
for me to convert the query on the left to the query on the right before chat gbt but I know it wouldn't have been fun
and we had to do this with dozens and dozens and dozens of
queries two is adding more indexes an index in yugabyte is a a new table that
recognizes reorganizes the data so it's easier to find for example if your query
is looking for all the book IDs by a particular author the index would sort the books table by the author's name in
alphabetical order without the index you'd have to look and specifically check each row to see if the author's
name matches the author you're looking for while inefficient this still might be fine when all of your data is on a
single postest server but when it's distributed amongst 10 servers this is a big Slowdown when using the index you
can skip directly down to where the author's name appears in the table and all of their books will be clumped
together for example if you're looking for all of Evan Winter's books you can skip down to the ease and quickly find
the first Evan winter entry then you can go down one by one until you see the first name that's not Evan winter in
this case it's Frank Herbert once you see Frank you could be confident that there are no more Evan Winters entries
anywhere else in the list because it's in alphabetical order the hard work was already done for you I found that due to
its distributed nature I've had to add a lot more indexes on yugabyte to keep my queries efficient but that's okay adding
too many indexes is only a problem when it slows down your ability to write to the database and with 10 extra servers
the extra capacity gain far outweighs the Slowdown of adding extra
indexes number three was denormalized tables I think of it like this a denormalized table is an index that can
organize data from multiple tables that's it imagine we have a book's table
a user table and a reviews table normally if you'd want to find all the authors that user has left reviews for
you would need a join query first it will find Rob's user ID in the user table then check the reviews table to
find all the book IDs that user have to review for then search the books table for those book IDs to find the author
for each book that's a lot of steps and if you've read hundreds or thousands of books it can take time to find all the
entes across all 10 servers with a denormalized table the relevant columns are put side by side in
the same table now the query goes from this with multiple joins to this much
more efficient the downside is you need to manage the denormalized table manually in your code anytime a a user
leaves a review you need to update the denormalized table too when a review is deleted you have to delete it from the
denormalized table to but this is doable and if you use Ruby on Rails rails triggers are easy way to manage that so
if you're dealing with a large postgress database that you need to Shard and you don't have the experience to do it look
in the yugabyte so I gave this talk at NDC Porto back in October and this slide is
pretty much where I ended it I had my master plan for getting through January 1st 2025 with self-hosted servers with
ukab DB and denormalized tables so how did it go went
okay in November about a month after my talk a few Tik Tok videos went viral about us and more people than ever were
visiting the site for context a year earlier we were seeing about 150,000 unique visitors to the app every day and
suddenly it spiked up to a million and the site was crashing again I went
through my checklist and after many hours I found the bottleneck the ha proxy server that was load balancing all
the yaby debut requests had completely saturated its Network CPU usage was low but the network connection simply
couldn't handle any more traffic so I took what I think is a completely reasonable next step and I just
installed ha proxy on all the web servers and I told them all to connect to Local Host on the ha proxy port to
get to the database now any network engineers in the audience might think this is crazy and you might be right I
don't know it works but I saw another potential botet coming up the number of database connections being used was
higher than I expected I usually address this by using PG bouncer which is a database connection Pooler that allows
your app to reuse existing connections allowing you to scale more easily with 10 servers I didn't think i' would need
it but I did so I installed PG bouncer on each web server which points to the
local ha proxy and the to topology ended up looking like this and the bottom neck was removed immediately everything was
fast again but that experience scared me it seems like whenever we reached a new
threshold of traffic New bottlenecks came up that were nowhere near being close on my radar
and January 1st typically has many many times higher traffic than a typical day if a typical day already has 1 million
